citations.narrative:
The licensee moved without submitting a change in address or requesting a new site. Animal Care must be informed of
any change in business address so that new locations can be approved for regulated activities and animal welfare
ensured through continued unannounced inspections. Licenses are issued to specific persons, and are issued for specific
activities, types and numbers of animals, and approved sites. A licensee must notify Animal Care prior to any change of
address where regulated activity occurs and the site must be approved prior to conducting regulated activity. Correct by
submitting a new site address by Sept 25, 2024.

Fifteen dogs were lacking required identification. Nine juvenile dogs older than 16 weeks did not have a permanent ID. Six
weaned puppies younger than 16 weeks were also lacking identification. It is important that all weaned dogs have
adequate identification so that their transfer, sale, and movement can be traced. All dogs older than 16 weeks must have
an individual permanent ID and weaned puppies younger than 16 weeks may have a temporary or permanent ID unique
to each puppy. Correct by Oct 1, 2024.

The licensee is not keeping updated acquisition records for dogs on hand. They did not have record of acquisition for
puppies and juvenile dogs born on property. Nine dogs older than 16 weeks and 25 dogs younger than 16 weeks did not
have any record of being born on property or otherwise acquired. Accurate acquisition/inventory information facilitates the
inspection process and ensures that dogs covered under the Animal Welfare Act can be traced. The licensee must make,
keep, and maintain records (forms 7005 and 7006) which fully and correctly disclose the required information concerning
each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control,
or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records must include
any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control.

Dogs housed in outdoor enclosures did not have access to a shelter structure. Fifteen dogs total, housed in 3 different
outdoor enclosures, did not have any shelter structure provided in their enclosures. The licensee stated that it was a
temporary housing situation but the dogs had been housed in these enclosures for at least 2 months. Shelter structures
allow dogs to stay warm and dry during inclement weather. All dogs housed in outdoor enclosures must have access to a
shelter structure that has a roof, a floor, 4 walls, and a wind break at the entrance and is large enough or provided in
sufficient quantity to accommodate all dogs in the enclosure, with enough space for them to sit, stand, and lay down in a
normal manner.
Correct by providing shelter structures in the outdoor enclosures by Sept 25, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
